content.description: Fun technical climbing That joins Dixie Crystals.
content.location: Second line from the left on Big Rock. Look for the tree right in front of the bolt line.

content.description: A variation of "Call of the Wild".  Starts up towards the chains at the dish located up about halfway up the route.  Once at the dish, follow the middle set of bolts that exit out the top of the dish.  The crux is leaving the dish and the moves above the dish are much thinner than below the dish.
content.protection: Bolts. There are 12 bolts on the second pitch.
content.location: Approximately the middle of the West Face.  Look for a dish about halfway up the middle of the wall.  The route follows the center clean line coming out of the top of the dish.

climbs.name: West Point
climbs.fa: Bob Ordner, Eric Barrett, Adam Volweiler

content.description: This enjoyable route climbs the center of the West Face. Positive holds and a few thoughtful moves will leave you satisfied.
content.location: In the middle of the wall, starting from a pointy foot rail thing. The only route between Council of Elders and Thrill of Krell.

content.description:
Scramble up the 4th class slab with your belayer to a belay ledge. There is a bolted anchor here for the belayer.

Pitch 1: 5.10a

Leave the left side of the ledge and enjoy a fun pitch with good holds where you want them. This is classic Big Rock. You have to love climbing here!

Pitch 2: 5.10b

From the anchor there are two options. The best one is to the right. Crimpy 5.10b face climbing will keep your attention - belay carefully here as it would be easy to fall onto the belay ledge.

A much easier option for the last pitch starts to the left of the belay anchor.
content.protection:
Well bolted route with anchors equipped for rappel.

If linking pitches, consider taking the easier (left-hand) second pitch option.  Your belayer will not be able to keep you off of the ledge if you fall on the cruxy 5.10b face climbing of the right option.
content.location: On the right side of the wall, the route goes up the left side of the small ceiling on top.

climbs.name: Small But Fancy
climbs.fa: Adam Volweiler, Eric Barrett, Bob Ordner (May 2013)

content.description:
Small But Fancy is an alternate route to the right of Satori that features an awkward but interesting chimney. To start either rap down from the top of Satori or climb Satori from its base. If starting at the base of Satori climb through the first section to a prominent ledge then continue up the thin second section to a 2nd ledge. Note the obvious corner to your right; the base of this is your goal. Do a thoughtful traverse down and move right on some slab to the base (be careful, a fall here could involve a significant swing). Setup for the route at the belay anchors at the base of the chimney and follow the obvious corner past 3 bolts with steep, fun stemming. The route shares the rap chains over the brow at the top with Satori.

Note: this was led by Adam Volweiler using huge cams (Valley Giants) for protection before he installed the bolts.
content.location: Either rappel from the top of Satori to the ledge or start at the base of Satori and climb about 2/3 of Satori to the ledge. Traverse right and aim for the chimney.

content.description: Climb slabby, fun moves to a prominent ledge with a tree/bush, which can also be accessed by scrambling from the left.  At this point you're facing the thin crux of the route, just above the ledge.  You do not want to fall here. After this, engage the flake system above that has a few suspect holds.  Traverse right from the flakes surmount a final boulder problem, and find the chains off to the left.
content.protection:
All bolted.  Two alpine draws are essential (a couple more are better) to limit rope drag high on the pitch.

Note: This route is not well-suited for top roping due to rope drag.
content.location: West Face of Big Rock, to the left of a chimney (the chimney is an alternate route called "Small But Fancy"). You'll climb to a ledge with a small tree/bush and then it's straight up!

climbs.name: The Issue
climbs.fa: Brad Gilbert, Bob Ordner, Rusty Bailie (June 2008)

content.description:
This is a nice two pitch route, but the pitches are very easily linked. To start, scramble up the 4th class slab and head up the middle line of bolts. Thrill of Krell is to the left and History Channel leaves the right side of the ledge.

Pitch 1: 5.7

The first pitch is a fun 5.7 with good holds, starting with some moves off of a flake.

Pitch 2:

The second pitch tackles the wild-looking roof. Well bolted, this is a safe place to try hard!
content.location: This route goes up the gnarliest looking roof on the West Face. There is a nice ledge with a bolted belay anchor after a short 4th class scramble below the route.  This belay ledge is shared with Thrill of Krell.

content.description:
Pitch 1: 11a Climb the burly undercling or offwidth past new glue in bolts. The angle and difficulty backs off to 5.8. Tape anyone?

Pitch 2: 11b Undercling #2 goes to the right. Get past thin climbing to another ledge with an anchor

Pitch 3: 10a Really short pitch over Tuolumne style knobs
content.location: About the left third on the west face. Look for the right leaning big crack and reconsider your life choices

climbs.name: The History Channel
climbs.fa: Aaron Henson, Rusty Baillie, Eric Barrett, Bob Ordner 2010

content.description: The large corner/off width left of Satori. Do it in two short pitches or one. Clip or skip the ancient 1/4" bolts as you work you way up and left. Plug a big cam or two and top out the corner. Find the Satori anchor/rap station to your right.
content.protection: Standard rack plus some big cams

content.description:
Shares the same anchors as the two B.O.B. routes, and requires 70-meter rope to safely lower from anchors. Extend the 7th draw to reduce rope drag.

Route is approximately 32 meters long and equipped with 3/8 SS Powers bolts and SS Fixe hangers.

Route developers: Bo H. and Pete S.
content.location: Look for the flake to the left of the two B.O.B. routes' chimney. Bolt line goes through the flake and on the left side of the upper arete.

content.description: Pitch 1 is 5.10b. This climb shares a start with Beautiful Disaster to the first bolt, then moves up and right. Second pitch tackles the roof above and goes at 5.11a.
content.location: Start on the first bolt line to the left of the West Face, but then split off to the right after the first bolt.

climbs.name: Council of Elders
climbs.fa: Bob Loomis, Rusty Baillie, Bob Ordner

content.description:
Pitch 1: 5.10a

Pull through some boulder moves at the start and countinue upward on good holds.  Bring an alpine draw for the bolt under a bulge and perhaps another for the final bolt.

Pitch 2: 5.10b

Head upwards to fun stemming and eventually working your way up a right-leaning crack.

Descent: Rappel the route.
content.location: This climb begins on the nice, flat ledge roughly in the middle of the West Face.  Council of Elders is the right-hand bolt line. A Perfect Storm is the left line of bolts. The bolts are camouflaged, so look carefully for the low first bolt.

content.description: Starts with easy climbing to a dish in the wall about halfway up the route.  Clip the chains at the dish or continue up to the top chains by following the bolts to the left side of the dish.  The crux is leaving the dish, but the rest of the climb is pretty straight forward on thin moves.
content.protection: 12 bolts with a set of chains half way up and a set of chains at the top.
content.location: Approximately located at the middle of the West Face.  Look for a big dish with three different clean streaks coming out the top of the dish.  The route follows the left clean streak.

content.description: Start up straight for the first bolt then climb a tricky slab that trends left. Finish below the big overhang. Legends of the Fall is the climb out the overhang above.
content.location: The far left climb of the West Face.

content.description:
Pitch 1: 5.11a

Climb the steep slab, snaking around bolts to find the crimpy holds. Two bolt anchor with rappel rings.

Pitch 2: 5.10b

Move through the obvious groove through the roof above on good holds.  After the crux bulge, continue straight up to the top of the wall and a bolted anchor. There is a bail-out anchor that you can reach after the crux via an easy ramp to the right, but don't do that!
content.location: Just to the right of a large flake system in the rock and a small tree.

climbs.name: B.O.B. Direct
climbs.fa: Eric Barrett, Bob Ordner, Rusty Baille 2009

content.description:
This is the original B.O.B. route, which takes the left of two bolt lines to the large chimney that faces South. Pitches 1 and 2 are easily linked.

Pitch 1: 5.9

The climbing is steep right off the ground. An initial crux is followed by an easy section and another fun, slabby boulder problem. Anchor bolts are at the base of the chimney.

Pitch 2: 5.7

Climb up the fun and airy 3-bolt chimney. A belay anchor is just above. Rap to the ground from here or continue to the summit via 4th class scrambling.
content.location: The left line of bolts leading to the SW chimney.

climbs.name: B.O.B.
climbs.fa: Eric Barrett, Bob Ordner and Rusty Baille (2011)

content.description:
The first and second pitches can be combined into one pitch but there will be significant rope drag.

First Pitch: Starts off with low grade slab climbing with a few chicken heads then gradually gets steeper at the crux before turning left and heading towards the chains.

Second Pitch: Climb up the 3 bolt chimney while trying to avoid getting stuck in it. The chains are at the top of the chimney, or you can scramble up a bit further to another set of chains (at the top of Satori) that can be rappelled off.

Optional summit pitch: climb above the pitch 2 belay anchor up to the summit via the obvious ridge line. There are a couple of bolts to clip into along the way. Once you get to a false summit, scramble up one last ledge to the true summit and look for the belay station above Northern Aggression which is slightly north east. *Summit rappel note: a 70m rope reaches the ground but a 60m rope will reach a slab near the bottom and then its an easy walk down.
content.protection: 5 bolts on the bottom section with rapel rings and an anchor station.  3 bolts in the chimney with your choice of chains on the chimney section.
content.location: The obvious large chimney that runs up the southwest corner of the Big Rock

content.description:
Pitch 1 - 5.8

Starts off with a bouldery move that isn't as hard as it looks.  Then meander up the face with good holds.  Follow the bolts to a small alcove under an overhang with a nice 2 bolt belay anchor.

Pitch 2 - 5.10b

Looking up you should see 4 bolt lines.  Perfect Storm is the right most one.  Climb up and right through the small roof at a crack.  Thin climbing follows the bolts to the top.

Rappel from the rap station on the north end of Big Rock.
content.protection: Lots of quickdraws.  The 2nd pitch has 12 bolts.
content.location: This climb is about in the middle of the west face on a large ledge.  Perfect storm is the bolt line of the left, Council of Elders is the bolt line on the right.
